item.title: Being an Alchemist is Awful
item.dc:creator: EvadableMoxie
item.description:
It’s not hard or easy, it’s largely beyond your control. You need to survive the entire game, but as the game goes on the list of suspects narrows. Someone steps on a trap and outs the Hunter. The Butler poisons the king and confirms. The psychic tells the Prince who they are. The Noble confirms via invisible whispers. The Priest reveals and isn’t counterclaimed or revives someone who becomes confirmed. The Sheriff/Paladin get the MM/Cult and everyone trusts them. Your acting like there’s always 10+ options and the Alchemist will never get picked unless the alchemist themselves does something to make themselves get picked, but that isn’t the case. In a game with good BD, an Alchemist is going to end up on a very short list of suspects and there really isn’t much an alchemist can do to prevent it. Yes, there are things you can do that are dumb and will get you checked but even if you do none of those things unless BD has leads, it’s likely at some point in the game you’ll get checked or at least voted up for your role.

But okay, let’s take a step back and take Allies and other checks out of the equation. Would you agree that if the majority of BD is of the opinion that Alchemists shouldn’t be lynched, especially Prince and King, that the game becomes much more difficult for the Alchemist? Because my main point is still that the attitude of others towards Alchemists in general, especially the BD power roles, is the biggest factor of an Alchemist’s success.

item.title: Being an Alchemist is Awful
item.dc:creator: EvadableMoxie
item.description:
The advice of ‘just don’t get checked’ isn’t really a counter-argument to how good or bad a class is. You can say that about literally every evil and most neutral classes. Everyone is trying not to be suspicious (Except the fool), it’s a social deduction game. Saying don’t be suspicious is like saying “Win a football game by having more points at the end.” You’re not wrong, but it’s also not really useful advice.

Other classes have tools to assist them not getting caught, which the Alchemist doesn’t. Most of those classes have a team so even if they die they can still win, which the Alchemist doesn’t. Scorned and Fool have goals that means they don’t have to survive the entire game, the Alchemist doesn’t. If BD is hostile to Alchemists then being an Alchemist is almost like being an NK but without the benefits.

Which means that surviving as an Alchemist if BD is hostile to you is much, much, harder than surviving when they are not. Not impossible, and good play can certainly nudge your odds up, but the single greatest factor in if you’ll win as an Alchemist is the attitude other players have toward Alchemists before the game even starts. I’ve seen people win as Alchemist, but 9 times out of 10 people knew they were an Alchemist before the end of the game and let them live. And in the small time this wasn’t the case, it was mostly that the game ended very quickly. I’ve never seen an Alch survive a 10+ day game without being outed.

I know players who say you should keep Alchemists around and I know players who say you should always kill them. Those players have made their minds up in advance and there is very little an Alchemist can do to change their mind. All they can do is hope they get lucky and end up with the people who keep Alchemists around. No class should have it’s biggest (Not only, but biggest) factor in their winning or not winning be the strategy of the other players.

item.title: Being an Alchemist is Awful
item.dc:creator: EvadableMoxie
item.description:
My problem with Alchemist isn’t so much the win rate, but how you win or lose.

Basically you have 2 options:

1: Claim Alchemist.

2: Lie.

Option 1: You are now fully at the Mercy of BD. You’ve basically taken the game out of your own hands and into someone elses and asked nicely to win. And when you win, you didn’t win because you outsmarted anyone, you didn’t win because you played well, you didn’t win due to any plays you made… you won because someone else allowed you to do so.

Option 2: Lie. Okay, well… If the King checks you? You’re dead. If you claim Phys and then 2 actual Phys die? You’re dead. One Phys died and the other counter claims you? Dead. If you claim anything else and can’t back it up with a good journal? Dead. You don’t get any evil versions of abilities like converted Unseen, nor do you have anyone to plot with and help your claims. The only possible ability that can confirm you is your heal, but again, if you claim Phys and someone gets poisoned? Yea, you’re dead.

Hell, just when it gets down to the wire you’re often dead because both BD and Unseen/Cult are happy to lynch you since you have nothing to confirm with and very little ways to fake other roles. When unseen/cult get to that critical point where they just have to dodge getting one of them executed for 1 or 2 more days to win, they’ll throw you right under the bus because the BD love killing neutrals, and that’s one more day they don’t have to worry about getting one of them lynched.

So, typically when you win by lying it’s because you were lucky enough not to get checked and the game moved quickly enough that you slid under the radar. Which again means you won not on your own merits, but because BD was kicking so much ass they never needed to really look into you, or Unseen murdered BD so quickly they never had a chance. And if it’s a cult game? Good fucking luck surviving one of those, there are so many days you’re getting executed at some point for sure.

That’s what bothers me about Alchemist. A balanced Win rate doesn’t mean a class is good, if you had a class that literally flipped a coin Night 1 and then won on heads and lost on tails it would have a 50% win rate but it would be a shitty class.

Alchemist does have some agency and every now and then you can make plays as an alchemist to speed up the game but in general, you’re playing a game that is mostly out of your hands.
